links.title: How long does it take for a train to come to a complete emergency stop?
links.description:
Answer (1 of 9): The other answers here that say “it depends” are of course correct. The main factors here are the speed of the train, and the condition of the railhead.

Faster trains will take longer to stop.

Poor railhead conditions (ice, water, leaf mulch, etc) will hugely increase stopping ...

links.title: How To Corrupt An SQLite Database File
links.description:
SQLite database files are ordinary disk files.
That means that any process can open the file and 
overwrite it with garbage.  There is nothing that the SQLite
library can do to defend against this.

links.title: Stinson Dean on the Lumber Crash That Followed the Boom
links.description: These days, commodities around the world are on a tear. But earlier this year, there was a lot of fixation on one in particular: lumber. Lumber went absolutely parabolic in the spring before collapsing rapidly. What's interesting is that this collapse was not due to a slowdown in housing per se. Housing is booming. Instead, it was a variety of idiosyncratic factors (including lumber storage availability) that caused the wild move. So, for this...

links.title: How a $2 Metal Plate Defeated the Laws of Supply and Demand
links.description: If you’ve ever cracked open a basic economics textbook, you’ve probably seen a chart that looks like this before. Two lines intersecting. One represents demand. One represents supply. And where they intersect reveals some kind of clearing price. If demand goes up, price goes up, and voila: Balance is achieved.

links.title: It Is Never a Compiler Bug Until It Is
links.description:
Last week I was trying to add some testing code to libsecp256k1 and I was pulling out my hair trying to get it to work.
No amount of printf was working to illuminate what I was doing wrong.
Finally, out of desperation, I thought I would do a quick check to see if there are any compiler bugs related to memcmp, and lo and behold, I found GCC bug #95189: memcmp being wrongly stripped like strcmp.

links.title: Does relativity lie at the source of quantum exoticism?
links.description: Since its beginnings, quantum mechanics hasn't ceased to amaze us with its peculiarity, so difficult to understand. Why does one particle seem to pass through two slits simultaneously? Why instead of specific predictions can we only talk about evolution of probabilities? According to theorists from universities in Warsaw and Oxford,	 the most important features of the quantum world may result from the special theory of relativity, which until now...

links.title: Quantum principle of relativity
links.description:
We show that the local and deterministic mode of description is not only in
conflict with the quantum theory, but also with relativity. We argue that
elementary relativistic properties of spacetime lead to the emergence of a
non-deterministic quantum-mechanical picture involving quantum superpositions
and complex probability amplitudes.

links.title: Quantum key distribution - Infogalactic: the planetary knowledge core
links.description: Quantum key distribution (QKD) uses quantum mechanics to guarantee secure communication. It enables two parties to produce a shared random secret key known only to them, which can then be used to encrypt and decrypt messages. It is often incorrectly called quantum cryptography, as it is the most well known example of the group of quantum cryptographic tasks.

links.title: Retrocausality in Quantum Mechanics (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
links.description:
Quantum theory provides a framework for modern theoretical physics
that enjoys enormous predictive and explanatory success. Yet, in view
of the so-called “measurement problem”, there is no
consensus on how physical reality can possibly be such that this
framework has this success. The theory is thus an extremely
well-functioning algorithm to predict and explain the results of
observations, but no consensus on which kind of objective reality
migh...

links.title: Fossil: Fossil Versus Git
links.description:
The feature sets of Fossil and Git overlap in
many ways. Both are
distributed
version control systems which store a tree of check-in objects to a
local repository clone. In both systems, the local clone starts out as a
full copy of the remote parent. New content gets added to the local
clone and then later optionally pushed up to the remote, and changes to
the remote can be pulled down to the local clone at will. Both systems
offer diffing, patch...

links.title: Little Interpreted Language
links.description:
LIL (stands for Little Interpreted Language)
is a small highly dynamic scripting language inspired by Tcl and
unix shells. LIL has two implementations, one written in C,
which consists of a pair of .c and .h files
and one in Free Pascal,
which consists of a single pas file (a unit). Also a
Lazarus package for the
latter is provided.

links.title: Announcing .NET MAUI Preview 4
links.description: Today we are pleased to announce the availability of .NET Multi-platform App UI (.NET MAUI) Preview 4. Each preview introduces more controls and features to this multi-platform toolkit on our way to general availability this November at .NET Conf. .NET MAUI now has enough building blocks to build functional applications for all supported platforms,

links.title: What if cemeteries played an essential role — on both the environmental and the human level — for the living?
links.description: If they’re not simply abandoned, they are accused of wastefulness and pollution: cemeteries have a hard life in our current times. And yet, they can play an essential role — on both the environmental and human levels — for those who are still living.
links.original_title: A Death Full of Life
